<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_alloc:
```c
static int lfs_dir_alloc(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_mdir_t *dir) {
    // allocate pair of dir blocks (backwards, so we write block 1 first)
    for (int i = 0; i < 2; i++) {
        int err = lfs_alloc(lfs, &dir->pair[(i+1)%2]);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    // zero for reproducibility in case initial block is unreadable
    dir->rev = 0;

    // rather than clobbering one of the blocks we just pretend
    // the revision may be valid
    int err = lfs_bd_read(lfs,
            NULL, &lfs->rcache, sizeof(dir->rev),
            dir->pair[0], 0, &dir->rev, sizeof(dir->rev));
    dir->rev = lfs_fromle32(dir->rev);
    if (err && err != LFS_ERR_CORRUPT) {
        return err;
    }

    // to make sure we don't immediately evict, align the new revision count
    // to our block_cycles modulus, see lfs_dir_compact for why our modulus
    // is tweaked this way
    if (lfs->cfg->block_cycles > 0) {
        dir->rev = lfs_alignup(dir->rev, ((lfs->cfg->block_cycles+1)|1));
    }

    // set defaults
    dir->off = sizeof(dir->rev);
    dir->etag = 0xffffffff;
    dir->count = 0;
    dir->tail[0] = LFS_BLOCK_NULL;
    dir->tail[1] = LFS_BLOCK_NULL;
    dir->erased = false;
    dir->split = false;

    // don't write out yet, let caller take care of that
    return 0;
}
```

I found no occurrences of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. The following points explain why other fragments do not need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 (language extensions):

- Declaration in the for-loop (for (int i = 0; i < 2; i++)): This is a standard C99 feature (block-scoped declaration) and is not a compiler-specific extension.
- Use of // single-line comments: These are part of standard C99 and later, not an extension.
- Use of bool, true, false: These are standard since C99 via _Bool and stdbool.h; their use is not a compiler extension (assuming standard headers are used in the project).
- Type casts and constant macro LFS_BLOCK_NULL ((lfs_block_t)-1): Standard C cast usage, not an extension.
- Bitwise and arithmetic operations (e.g., ((lfs->cfg->block_cycles+1)|1), lfs_alignup, etc.): Plain standard C expressions.
- Pointer usage, struct and typedef declarations, conditional compilation (#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE): All are standard preprocessor and language features.

No constructs such as compiler-specific keywords or attributes (e.g., __attribute__, __builtin_*, __asm__), inline assembly, nonstandard calling conventions, variable-length arrays used as GCC/clang extensions, Microsoft-specific extensions, or other documented compiler-only extensions are present in the snippets provided.
